results.title: The Discovery of television
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Milne, JBM Productions, BBC-TV and John Lloyd
results.brief_description: The discovery and development of television is not the story of the efforts of a single person, but of many people. It is a search through a tangled web of scientific discoveries, inventions, and developments, of ideas tried and rejected and tried again, culminating with the efforts of an enthusiastic team of professionals led by Sir Isaac Shoenberg. Describes the early experiments in television leading to the first regular broadcasts from London beginning on 2nd November 1936. The work of the pioneers is reconstructed using contemporary records and interviews.

results.title: The Discovery of radium
results.creator_credit: James Fonda, CBS TV America and Bernard Girard
results.brief_description: Henri Becquerel a French scientist while studying uranium discovers properties hitherto unknown to the scientific world. The substance emitted rays that could penetrate black paper and leave an impression on a sensitive photographic plate. Pierre Curie and his wife Marie discover the unknown element, radio-active radium. The significance of their discovery was realised and the novelist Jules Verne considers that the possible results of the Curie’s work could be fantastic. He remarks that it is God’s glory to make a secret of things - man’s glory to uncover them. Presented by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Discoverers
results.brief_description: A look at several scientific discoveries and techniques and their implications for the future of humanity - the laser, the fuel cell, urethane foam, the petrochemicals, cross-pollination of technologies, a jet piercing drill and micro-circuitry.

results.title: The Directors
results.brief_description: A ‘Life Magazine’ reporter attempts to analyse the traits of a good director, talking to such noted directors as David Lean, Igmar Bergman, Kurosawa, Fellini and Hitchcock. Discusses the evolution of neo-realism, the technical advances that have brought about cinema verite and the New Wave directors and their influence.

results.title: The Director
results.brief_description: Director Don Weis bears the responsibility of supervising every aspect of putting a film together. His talent must encompass acting, camera work, special effects, music, costumes, make-up, scripts, editing and budgeting. This film places the viewer beside a skilful director as he gives shape to a major Hollywood production. Features Robert Wagner in acting role.

results.title: The Diode: principles and applications
results.brief_description: Explains the principles of electron flow across a gap, basic features of the diode tube, control of the electron flow in the tube, photoelectric cells, x-ray tubes, and the diode as a rectifier.

results.title: The Dinosaur who wondered who he was
results.brief_description: Diplodocus, who has a lot to learn about the world, saves himself and his friends Stegosaur, Brontosaur and Pterodactyl from the terrible Allosaur in Murky Swamp.

results.title: The Dinosaur age
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: Describes the work of two palaeontologists looking for fossils on a rocky hillside. They uncover the paddle or flipper of a plesiosaur which was a large water living reptile or sea serpent closely related to dinosaurs. The methods used to uncover the bones, preserve them, and transport them to a museum are shown, also the tedious work of assembling the bones, fitting them in position and reconstructing the entire animals are explained. Models of representative animals of the age of dinosaurs are shown.

results.title: The Digital Environment - Information about Australia's Culture and New Technologies
results.brief_description:
This CD provides an information resource about the intersection of new technologies and cultural activities including: web-publishing, copyright, interoperability, digitisation and other aspects of the Internet age.

Extensive video, reports, discussion papaers, glossaries and other material are available on the CD. There is a powerful index to search thense resources, and it contains hyperlinks to quickly access documents on the Web if your computer has an Internet connection.
